abstract: <jats:p> The United States has an Economic Constitution, governing federal regulation, and explaining how to conduct regulatory impact analysis, with reference to quantification and monetization of the costs and benefits of proposed and final regulations. Known as OMB Circular A-4, the Economic Constitution of the United States was thoroughly revised in 2023, with new directions on behavioral economics and nudging; on discount rates and effects on future generations; on distributional effects and how to account for them; and on benefits and costs that are hard or impossible to quantify. The revised document leaves numerous open questions, involving (for example) the valuation of human life, the valuation of morbidity effects, and the value of the lives of children. </jats:p>
title: The Economic Constitution of the United States

affiliation.name: Cass R. Sunstein is the Robert Walmsley University Professor, Harvard Law School, Cambridge, Massachusetts. From 2009 to 2012, Sunstein served as Administrator, Office of Information and Regulatory Affair, Washington, DC. From 2021 to the present, he has also served as senior counselor and consultant with the Department of Homeland Security, where he has occasionally been involved in discussions of some of the issues explored in this essay. .
